It’s been really an amazing guild. I have completely missed DeFi in KB4. This often reminds me of our conversation, @johnx25bd right at the beginning of KB4. Thanks <!subteam^S01JV5JPV6E|@kernel-stewards> for keeping this space so welcoming, beautiful and full of life.

With endless thanks to so many people in KB5, @Ali Rizvi @Jing Yi Teo @Nicholas Sheaf @horsefacts @Holly Grimm @johnx25bd @John Ellison @Ben Percifield @Yulia Babanova @kei @Isaac Patka @Danny Gattas @Julian Traversa @Salim Virani and many, many more - we have the biggest PR for the block so far with all your wonderful resources put in their places of honour: <https://github.com/kernel-community/kernel-v2/pull/306>

My heart overflows :kernel-love:

Thank you @Julian Traversa for the office hours and encouraging me to build. 

Some of you might relate to this but I sometimes find it challenging to get started when there are so many technologies that I don't know about yet. The feeling of always playing catch up or not feeling good enough or expert enough to contribute yet.

It's constant work to overcome that feeling but I am thankful to all of you for being kind and encouraging.

Thanks for everything, Kernel. I'm filled with joy at all the connections I've made and the great conversations I've had. More than that, I'm looking forward to the conversations I'm going TO have! In no particular order @cryptowanderer's fantastic and challenging syllabus, @Ali Rizvi's great chats, @Greg Bateman's good suggestions, @Danny Gattas's invitations to be a part of the DeFi Guild and @horsefacts's great intro to MEV. @Salim Virani big thanks for making the sessions more interactive! All of you who attended our chats, esp @Adam Lieber (your enthusiasm to learn is inspiring) and @Juan Diosdado / @Cedric Tiu /@Jason Mah /@Yajie Wang thanks again! Thanks to @Vivek Singh for being the glue that holds this all together. It was also great to connect with @Kokeb Solomon and @Jonathan Brun in real life. Super excited to see where this all goes in the future!

Thank you from the KERNEL community to our courageous steward of care, @Vivek Singh. 

Yesterday Vivek led a conversation at the ETHDenver event <https://schellingpoint.gitcoin.co/|Schelling Point> on *Communities of Care*. The presentation was a beautiful representation of our community. Thank you for leadership, for acknowledging members of the community and sharing universal knowledge. 

I am grateful that I was able to support you IRL with Kernel friends @johnx25bd, @Paul Gadi and @Muhammad Hameed. 

Vivek wore a beautiful scarf (see the picture to confirm consensus). @cryptowanderer’s spirit was felt :kernel-love: 

Shoutout to Kernel Fellows at the event: @Aliya, @Abe Uccello and @Kyle Smith (sorry for anyone I missed :pray::skin-tone-6:)
Very thankful for @Anna Alexa, @cryptowanderer , @Greg Becker , @Tim Courtney ,  @Saskia Westhof, and @johnx25bd for their invaluable feedback and help! :deciduous_tree: :deciduous_tree:

Wow, is all I can say. I didn’t know what to expect coming in, other than Kernel came highly recommended from a friend who’s worked in crypto for years. I’m amazed by all of the incredible, talented, warm, and kind people here. I feel that I’ve only scratched the surface of meeting people and going deeper into the conversations this has sparked. Thanks so much to @cryptowanderer @Vivek Singh and the team for curating such a transformational experience. I also appreciate folks like @johnx25bd @alisha @Vivek Singh as mentors for generously giving your time on calls! Wonderful to have calls with @Michael Keating @snax y-not @Matthew Scott Jones @Denise Schaefer and have great junto conversations with folks like @Renee Maria Lee @Divine Artis @Jake Becker @Ela + participating in the Declaration of Interdependence with @Jasmine Wang and the climate lightning talks with @Vienna Looi!

Here’s to this only being the beginning! I’m looking forward to transitioning full time into web3 projects and startups and I’m looking forward to collaborating with you all. :kernel-love:

I see there's many emotions building in each one of us being expressed in various ways, beautiful to see it all and the journey that we embarked together. If this is just the starting, can't imagine the beauty of the game ahead!

@Renee Maria Lee @Vienna Looi @Sachin Mittal @Vivek Singh @Michael Keating @Martin Etzrodt @O'Plerou Grebet @Ben Percifield @Erin Pangilinan @sidcode @alisha @Tommy Nienchi Chen @Sister Tibebwa @Ai Tuonoin @Amarnath Jayanti @Bella Dokell @johnx25bd & many more I've met on this journey and yet to meet :pray: deep gratitude and  :heart: love for sharing the space you all did!

Extremely grateful to @johnx25bd for bringing KERNEL into my life. I feel lit up :fire: for the journey to come, the learnings and growth, and the relationships to be cultivated. Looking forward to meeting many of you!

Truly grateful to have been part of this journey. The past 8 weeks have been quite memorable for me. The conversations, the lessons, the people, everything that makes KERNEL "KERNEL" came together and made it wonderful. Not enough can be said to thank all the Stewards who paved this entire block @Vivek Singh @Angela Gilhotra @Sachin Mittal @cryptowanderer @johnx25bd and everyone else involved! This experience was a gift, and I am glad I was one of the few lucky ones to be able to receive it so far.

Thanks to all the mentors and guests who took time off their hectic days to talk to us Fellows, and guide us through our journey. The juntos, fireside, KERNEL Cafe, One-to-one Offerings, etc. was just beautiful. I am glad I was able to speak with many of you in <!subteam^S0224NELPGD|@kb3> and I hope we keep the ties strong. I love how everyone in this group is either building something or looking for inspiration to start. I love what everyone is working on, and I wish everyone the best in their journeys from here on.

Lots of gratitude and love to you all!

“Know that thankfulness is from the highest of stations, and it is higher than patience and fear and detachment of this world.”  - Imam Al-Ghazali

Cultivating gratitude is the most beautiful art we can create. The social, emotional dynamics and constant personal growth that is required for the deep collaboration that forges hyper effective teams is grossly understated. For that reason I am grateful to my friend, peer, co-founder and comrade in Web 3 @Tagan Horton. Without her spirit, energy, fortitude and self determination the KERNEL experience and Dakar Gallery would not be possible. 

KERNEL has been a lesson in play and a journey of gratitude. While it is impossible to pinpoint one person or Kernel experience I am grateful to @Vivek Singh for setting the tone for gratitude per our first conversation days before KERNEL started. Furthermore I’m forever grateful for the insight and wisdom shared by @cryptowanderer that both challenged me yet made me feel at home in my personal study; and for @Sachin Mittal, @johnx25bd and the inspiration and feedback from @Jeet Raut, @Nuno Neto, @Abe Uccello, @tina, @Paul Gadi, @Paulo Almeida @Rahul // r-nk.xyz @Rajesh Kadam @Reuben Bramanathan @Rebecca Mqamelo. Just to name a few. To all those I Kernel that I have spoken with and listened to I am forever grateful. 

“May the gratitude in my heart Kiss all the Universe” - Hafiz

Thanks @sidcode. And hey @Jason Mah and @Adam Lieber. Short answer: We think it fits very well! For example, the power of AI is highly concentrated in the hands of a few. Data scientists usually don't own what they create and users of AI apps don't own their data. This means value flows to few, which will be more of an issue as AI and automation becomes a larger part of economies. We're trying to figure out what the Web3 machine learning stack looks like (e.g. storage, compute, marketplace, private AI, coordination). And also what ethics and safety looks like for decentralized AI. Would love if you were interested in getting involved!

U016Q117G67.message: Thanks for everything, Kernel. I'm filled with joy at all the connections I've made and the great conversations I've had. More than that, I'm looking forward to the conversations I'm going TO have! In no particular order @cryptowanderer's fantastic and challenging syllabus, @Ali Rizvi's great chats, @Greg Bateman's good suggestions, @Danny Gattas's invitations to be a part of the DeFi Guild and @horsefacts's great intro to MEV. @Salim Virani big thanks for making the sessions more interactive! All of you who attended our chats, esp @Adam Lieber (your enthusiasm to learn is inspiring) and @Juan Diosdado / @Cedric Tiu /@Jason Mah /@Yajie Wang thanks again! Thanks to @Vivek Singh for being the glue that holds this all together. It was also great to connect with @Kokeb Solomon and @Jonathan Brun in real life. Super excited to see where this all goes in the future!

I begin this post-Kernel weeks with overwhelming gratitude for the profound support I have received as I embark on helping people build Gift Economy communities. I am drawing heavily on Module 7. Thank you @Christina Trout and @cryptowanderer and my unseen wisdom guides who know it is possible to build a new world, starting now with simplicity and love.

Your conversations, and my connections with you, which have been built around the beautiful syllabus that @cryptowanderer and @Vivek Singh and the team have developed and delivered to us has impelled me to shift course. I am grateful. I wake each day with a joy and focus that springs me into the awaiting opportunities still possible. Being with you all has catalyzed me to spend the rest of my time developing gift economy communities.  The winds are. sweeping. clear the way and as Machado reminds us/me - Traveller, there is no path, you make the path by walking.  You will always walk by my side.  I am so very thankful to you all.

As we close off KB5, I would like to thank every wonderful person I meet during my adventure. Sorry being a nerd , really not good at fancy words to express my gratitude. I must say that starting Trust to Gift, every block inspired my work and encourage me to build up a better World collectively. I’m very thankful for answering my call to ‘Help’ ,it is a Gift to me. One thing I’m upset about is to not contribute grants enough, I think that every effort here should be rewarded. I wish I can help more in upcoming rounds. And lastly, Let’s keep our hearth open in the hell : <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ym4Rpd72tq8> , thanks for doing Kernel @cryptowanderer @Vivek Singh @sidcode @Aliya @Sachin Mittal  :sunflower:
@cryptowanderer we made this one unrecorded upon request! Made sure to get some insights documented on the <https://www.figma.com/file/bgO0UVUvwQ04QFtDM341YL/Jam---Funding?node-id=0%3A1|figma> tho.
@cryptowanderer thank you for your kind and generous attention to long-ago ideas.

Thanks @Jason Mah for advice on my presentation / deck :grinning:, yesterday was a rollercoaster but a great step in some kinda direction, I think.  Thanks @Salim Virani for a wonderful conversation a few days ago and introducing me to your great ways of thinking and bringing me into the fold of your conversations on how we may create a more collaborative, organic and fluid way of being as communities/collectives :pray::genie: your project and ways of thinking are wonderful/inspiring. 
@Abe Uccello thank you for grounding me and bringing me back to reality yesterday, my approach needs a huge overhaul :grimacing:, but this is a step forward. I love your work and your prison project with @cryptowanderer  is so humbling :hugging_face:.

i'm also grateful for the kernel curriculum (@cryptowanderer or whoever wrote this part!)-- for introducing me to this ENTIRE 20+ HOUR COURSE on how money actually works in the world today, which i have never understood in the slightest (aside from The Big Short which is one of my favorite movies), but have always wanted to understand. in fact, crypto in general has been my catalyst for finally learning the basics about conventional non-crypto economics/finance, like what it means when the news says the US federal reserve is doing X or Y. and i can't wait to watch this series and evolve into a full-on geek about liquidity and balance sheets~
<https://www.ineteconomics.org/education/courses/the-economics-of-money-banking>

@Sparrow Read @Alon Rapaport @cryptowanderer @Ali Rizvi @Kyle Nelson and Adam on sharing your thoughts on translations, web2 translations structures, communities, experiences in multi-lingual Discord chats and most importantly asking much much better questions, I am so deeply grateful :thank_you:

Thanks @Ines Pereira for our chat around desci, circular funding ideas, vita dao and more! Thanks @nickrizzo for sharing your project and generally just being a superb person to bounce ideas with! @Juan Diosdado for continually dumfounding me with your warm and questioning mind @Jason Mah for your sanity and willingness to learn and share ideas and help and the awesome fiction and narratives convo, looking forward to next one. @Ali Rizvi for getting the first london meetup going, I need to instigate one next. @sidcode for your usual constant goodness and help. @cryptowanderer for continually surprising and grounding me. @Abdi Shemsu for articulating some of my thoughts so clearly beautifully and showing interest in the adventure hovering above us asking to be pulled into our pluriverse. @LCC for another great glass bead game session. @Jing Yi Teo for sharing more insights into your journey and work you are building maybe we will align. and all those who joined the talk on wellness & web3

Thanks to @cryptowanderer or whoever wrote this

The starting point is to ask yourself, "What does this really mean?" It's not about "How can I use this?" or "Why is everyone else excited?" It's about whether you can understand the basic principles.

Resonates so deeply, helpful for making sense of cryptoverse and way beyond

There are far too many people to thank but here goes. Thanks for letting me cry in Twitter Spaces today @Vivek Singh @alisha @Angela Gilhotra @cryptowanderer @Sachin Mittal. In KB4, I've bonded, spent time with or been in the presence with these amazingly inspirational womxn of color @Vienna Looi @Songyi Lee @Holly Grimm @Jasmine Wang @Michelle Ma @Denise Schaefer @Rebecca Mqamelo @Juanna Zhai. I've been so moved by the work of @Richard Blythman @Matthew Scott Jones that I hope for the future of the “metaverse” and AI, places where I have felt trapped in centralized recreating inequalities for so long, that it's such a fresh breathe of air to see these amazing founders for their work and I can't wait to see more from them and work with them somehow in some fashion at the intersection as its relevant with my work in the future. I have an extremely long list of all the folks who demo’ed today at Showcase and Expo that I either plan on somehow integrating into in my future work (be a user, beta tester, adviser on their platform). Thank you (Salamat) again to @Alex Yao Lisa Lee Lucas (co-founder of NOVA with @Nicolas Nicolas Ponette) and Michelle Tsing (laptopradio and blockchain adviser to some companies out of Kernel and Blockchain at Berkeley accelerator) for pushing me to apply. I almost didn't and I am so glad I did. It is really encouraging me to do all the things I want to with DAOs, to not compromise my values, and stay true to myself, in a world obsessed with performative isms that is the Hollywood/Silicon Valley/DC/NY power and wealth hungry addicted and controlling egos that I try so hard to resist. Today I quit 3 social media networks, dropped 3 projects that no longer made sense, and am deciding to double down on what I believe is authentic to my nature and being, that will continue to serve me well personally and professionally in my work. Thank you so much for helping me verbally process, grow, raise hard and contentious questions and receive so many more resources and feedback I am still processing I feel like I did 5 MOOCs and a degrrr in Kernel it was far more than I expected than a YC, graduate degree, or self-help coaching session. This has been powerful for me as a community organizer, entrepreneur, software engineer, computational designer, as a woman of color, colonized person, and avid reader. I so appreciate all the hard work it takes to create content, organize logistics, moderate, facilitate, and maintain as a steward and also much love to every single person in the Kernel community who has been responsive with every chat, every request, and every ask I have made whether verbal, written or otherwise. I am constantly amazed by this community and am so privileged to be a part of it. It's been an honor to be selected as a fellow and I can only hope I live up to what I set out to do next now with a framework that helps heal me and keep me grounded away from a hamster wheel that is life. I am taking a major cooling period after December and hope to share more work come 2022 with Kernel (maybe a future showcase), of all that's been incubating and cooking up in my head, behind Code editors and things I haven't pushed to GitHub, announced or made live yet. Lastly, thank you @Kevin Owocki for founding GitCoin, seeing you speak at Dystopia Labs and other conferences over the years always impressed me and I'm floored to have participated somehow in some small way related remotely to the work that you do, it is so important for the liberation of all people in the world and I hope that it continues to evolve with each Kernel block in the future.

Wow, is all I can say. I didn’t know what to expect coming in, other than Kernel came highly recommended from a friend who’s worked in crypto for years. I’m amazed by all of the incredible, talented, warm, and kind people here. I feel that I’ve only scratched the surface of meeting people and going deeper into the conversations this has sparked. Thanks so much to @cryptowanderer @Vivek Singh and the team for curating such a transformational experience. I also appreciate folks like @johnx25bd @alisha @Vivek Singh as mentors for generously giving your time on calls! Wonderful to have calls with @Michael Keating @snax y-not @Matthew Scott Jones @Denise Schaefer and have great junto conversations with folks like @Renee Maria Lee @Divine Artis @Jake Becker @Ela + participating in the Declaration of Interdependence with @Jasmine Wang and the climate lightning talks with @Vienna Looi!

Here’s to this only being the beginning! I’m looking forward to transitioning full time into web3 projects and startups and I’m looking forward to collaborating with you all. :kernel-love:

I am simply grateful for the wonderful fellows I have met from all around the world! Web3 knows no borders, and it is amazing to know that there are so many talented fellows in all corners of the globe who are building and contributing in the space. Thank you @Vivek Singh @cryptowanderer @Sachin Mittal @alisha @Angela Gilhotra for facilitating Block 4 and giving us all the opportunity to meet and learn from each other through the program. I hope to meet many of you on my travels (in this post COVID world) whether it's at a Web3 conference, on holidays or through social meetups :kernel-love::ablobattentionreverse:

I would like to express my gratitude to Kernel in every possible way. I have learned so much during my journey here and very grateful to everyone I met during the last 2 months. I realized how little I knew and yet have to discover for web3 adventure I envisoned. My adventure is just starting and the lessons I learned will definitely help me along the way.
Kernel - is one of the greatest gifts Web3 movement can give to the world. One of the learning materials has a piece about reclaiming our time from Douglas Rushkoff. Mr. Rushkoff is a big believer in humanity and optimization of technologies for humans, not the other way around. I feel that Kernel is doing the things that global thinker is talking about all the time: creating an environment to build technologies for Humans.
So, thank you @Vivek Singh @cryptowanderer @Sachin Mittal and everyone else who I have met here. I loved all the conversations we had and hope to continue them in the future. :kernel-love::shamrock::wink:

I couldn’t let this experience end without sending some love to the KB4 community. Kernel has been an amazing journey and I think the best part is that it feels like the start of an even richer adventure. I’ve had some incredible conversations over the past 8 weeks, but wanted to say a special thanks to a few people:
• @Jasmine Wang for an intellectual brunch that opened up a number of new paths for me :sailboat: 
• @Michael Zargham for helping me sift through the noise and zero in on where I want to focus :dart: 
• @cryptowanderer for (per usual) providing a level-headed perspective on this world :male_mage: 
• @snax y-not for riffing on food, fun, and the future of franchises :pizza: 
• @Michael Keating for comparing notes in the early days and spearheading the tokenomics guild :scales: 
• my ~girlfriend~ fiance for providing endless support and agreeing to marry me back in week 3 :ring: 
I’m gutted to miss the final session today (will be traveling :disappointed:), but I take solace in the fact that I’ll see you all out in the garden very soon :slightly_smiling_face:

Before starting KERNEL, I knew I wanted to build a dApp but had no idea what to build, how to build and who to build it with. Now at the end of KERNEL, not only I learnt so much about Web3, I went on an adventure with a wonderful team and made a beautiful prototype and working on a potentially world-changing idea. Thank you @Nate Jacobs and @Martin Etzrodt  and @Eddy Schauman-Haigh @Bolo Michelin @Amir Jabarivasal , also many others who have supported us along the way, particularly  @Brent Annells  and @Anuj Kodam for your generous connection and advice, and the wonderfully eloquent , generous and wise @cryptowanderer.  Now KB4 is ending but my web3 journey has just started. Thank you <!subteam^S01JV5JPV6E|@kernel-stewards> for bringing in such wonderful people and creating this high trust space for magic to happen. :pray::kernel-love::shamrock::rainbow::heart::pray:

Is it just me? Or does anyone else feel like when @cryptowanderer speaks, he’s speaking directly to me/you?

Here are just a couple of things (paraphrased) I heard him say for which I now have potent gratitude for:

```"The wise sage gives only from a place of emptiness"

"Sometimes the hardest part of giving is finding those ready to receive"```
Of course he has said so many generous things it’s impossible to give a full account. The man is a gift that keeps on giving.  It suddenly feels absurd to say this because I’m not even sure I know the difference between giving and receiving anymore. It’s just that the things he says, and the place from which he says them makes being in the confusion of gift-space palpable  :evergreen_tree::pray::evergreen_tree:

The entire curriculum, I just keep finding (and not finding) treasures. @cryptowanderer  your poetic word-thought eloquence is beyond powerful/inspiring/beautiful/ albeit overmyhead at times. Eternal gratitude

I thought I'd drop a line here as I'm just jumping back into Kernel after quite a time away.  My web3 journey didn't start with Kernel but it did start with Gitcoin back in early 2019 after I heard a podcast with @Kevin Owocki that was my first step down the rabbit hole.  After hacking away on bounties for more than year (quite a few for Gitcoin Core), I saw the first mentions of the Kernel program and applied.  After a fruitful interview with @Vivek Singh and @Sachin Mittal, I waited a few weeks and wondered if I'd ever hear back.  I feel like the poster child for imposter syndrome in the web3 world and I was more than surprised when I got the email inviting me to join the Kernel Genesis Block.  The rest, as they say, is history.  I'm thankful for having been included in this community of builders and thinkers and also for the whole Gitcoin community of growing open source .  I'm definitely not the deepest thinker here or the best coder (not by a country mile), but it was this community that really helped me find my footing to go from where I was (someone who felt purposeless and unfruitful in my then vocation) to where I am now (an active, engaged dev working on Ethereum infrastructure who wakes up every day excited to do what I've been called to do and to see the world get turned upside down by what we're building).  So thank you @Kevin Owocki for building Gitcoin, @Vivek Singh, @Sachin Mittal,  and@cryptowanderer for Kernel, and to others along the way who have given me opportunities to build cool stuff and to be a part of web3 like @Rob Secord and @Ben Lakoff from Charged Particles, @Mike Elias from Idea Market, various folks from the Status/Nimbus team, @Shresth Agrawal, @Jose Aguinaga...etc.
Love it, reading this has re-energized me. Thanks for helping us find true voice @cryptowanderer! :heart: :rainbowheart: :kernel-love:

Hey all, time flew, and now with things calming down a bit, I want to express my gratitude towards those that made the past few months so special, It was a big wave for me and ethblockart, and without the help of mentors, fellows, and the kernel team, I wouldn't have been able to stay atop the surfboard!

For starters, I wanna express my gratitude towards many of the mentors, present and supportive in genuinely important ways throughout this adventure: Defi_Dad, @Thomas Klocanas, @Linda Xie, @Shawn Cheng @Ben Lakoff, @Dave Rodman, @Harsh Rajat and @Scott Moore. You folks are amazing and your help instrumental.

Other fellows, always positive, helpful and inspiring in the best way possible even while busy with their own adventures, like @Simon Fremaux, @Carter Carlson and the best-practices gang, @Holly Grimm, and the DADA team, even if we didn't interact much directly, know you've been an inspiration for many years!

And how can we not be grateful for the Kernel team, receiving us all with open arms and unparalleled patience and kindness, @Sachin Mittal, @Vivek Singh and others, one-of-a-kind human beings which I'm honoured to have met and spend time with. :pray:

Lastly, I can't write this without a special note to @cryptowanderer, embracing the project mission from the start, contributing in ways I couldn't have expected, making what the project is today a reality, you're amazing, thank you again.

One can say riding a market like we're experiencing today as a solo builder with a somewhat market-fit product can feel like choosing Jaws, Maui as a go-to surf spot while still learning to surf, sure some can pull off the once-in-a-lifetime herculean task of achieving so alone...But what enables surfers to, time and time again, execute this impressive feat, a humbling celebration of our ability to face head-first the scariest challenges posed by nature, are exactly other humans, community, supporters often not celebrated, from the tow-in jet sky riders, the lifeguards bringing you oxygen, to the chanting crowd by the coast and even the sharks keeping you alert.

Back to the point, what is being done here at Kernel is unique, every step planned with a level of care hard to find elsewhere, and it is also upon us all to keep this flame awake and the kernel culture principled, I hope to in the future be able to help others the same way I was helped here, for that is what makes the world go round.

For now, thank you Kernel, for all, and happy spring! :seedling:

Here are left over thoughts & some notes from our last Junto that may lend to David’s thoughts on indigenous influence in our urgent times. His great articulation of the benefits of consensus & the creation of new bottom up structures-- seems to speak to where the weight of transformative power of indigenous dialogue resides. Not having to start from scratch in autonomous creation of new sustainable structures is a huge advantage we shouldn’t take for granted on any front.

Insights to western misnomers of indigenous social structures through a matrilineal indigenous & _Kanienke'ha'ka perspective (misnomer - Mohawk)_: 

Female/Male Chief = “The Best of us”-- chosen by women title-holders with 100% consensus decision making. “(De)horned” by women when deemed ineligible for title. No campaigns or elections, to avoid any “perception of corruption.” Perceptions of possible pillow talk amongst representatives means title-holders can not be married to each other for example.

Hereditary - Is reference to clan —not blood, or immediate family. Used as mechanism to protect against nepotism or any “perceptions of corruption,” not to ensure nepotism as in the western context. Even if not blood & across the territory for example— inter clan marriage is illegal. Representatives can not hand down title to their children-- as in the western meaning of hereditary monarchies. Clan is blood only in the case that legally clan can only be given by mother to children. If your mother is does not have a clan but your father does you are his  “__” clan “hung about the neck.” This becomes relevant in case of legal title eligibility. 

Elected Tribal or Band councils across the hemisphere today do not abide by any of these native constitution laws —their chief title only being legal in context of municipalities of respective colonial nations — which means they have signed away their rightful nation to nation status of the Two Row Wampum Peace Treaty. We can never express our gratitude to the women of the Longhouse in Kahnawake, who have kept this Peace Treaty alive for us to leverage today. 

Slavery - The Longhouse is adamant about the absence of slavery in the hemisphere. The Longhouse is also always careful not to speak on the protocols of other native nations. So this strong stance on slavery is likely a reference to the continuity that also exist amongst those distinctions—from a common history & cosmology “the journey of the corn.”

This is consistent with the Longhouse’s oral documentation of “the bringing into the heart fire” concept of indigenous ”justice systems.” Hereditary in the indigenous context becomes important in Wengrow’s mention of “hereditary slavery”--because it likely points to an adoption into clan mechanism, merely getting lost in an ethnographic translation. To jail or imprison a human being in Longhouse oral documentation has always been illegal. So it follows that anything even closely resembling the chattel style slavery we attach to the word would inherently be deemed illegal as well. The worst of crimes meant being marked on the face as the worst of offenders, to be easily identified by surrounding nations -- then let free in to the wilderness. Or killed immediately for the heinous offense. 

Hinting at possible matrilineal continuity across oceans — this is also consistent with other matrilineal justice mechanisms of Africa. Mentioned by polymath, physicist, anthropologist, archaeologist, linguist, historian —Cheikh Anta Diop. Diop describes precolonial west African nations having intricate protocols for bringing local/regional rule benders into the family for a determined period of time —after which it was then illegal to ever disparage the person by even mentioning the crime or this time of the person’s life. 

This last nuance actually points to elaborate cultural protections against free labor —as does clan adoption via “bringing into the heart fire” in the native context. 

Chattel slavery is largely dependent on quite the contrary elaborate cultural mechanisms of dehumanization — rhetoric of infidels was just as pop culture as minstrel shows, toys, cartoons food labels & children restaurants called “Little Black Sambo” as recent as the 80s here in the states for example. These indigenous systems seem to be humanizing as much as possible with protections against dehumanization.

This makes lot more sense than this “heart fire” phrasing being a sick euphemism for what is the Islamic origin of chattel slavery ,in which we are the most familiar in the west. As Graeber mentions the folks in the 1500s having a hard time believing natives had even heard of Jesus let alone (or practice human sacrifice to demons) denounce him. This may be a continuation of this same phenomenon via the slavery misnomer that is rooted in old world religious, political & economic systems. Far removed from a precolonial native world. 

“The forgotten slave trade” of east Africa & what was then — extensions of these east African nations into the Middle East. Resulted in an ethnic cleansing not unlike what has happened in modern Palestine in our lifetime. It also lasted long enough to overlap with the west African slave trade. 
Not unlike our real time awareness of geopolitics today, important history of both eras of African slavery are largely lost to highly politicized & or religious narratives, somehow skipping over indigenous spiritual/cultural influence in the regions for millenia. Diop mentions interesting west African context often left out — the “bringing into the heart fire” style justice systems were still intact in these still precolonial black African nations — this was exploited by slave traders before raids became necessary because these nations rose to the defense of their people after discovering the crime. 

None of this takes away from Graeber’s overall point of empirical political data over millenia giving robust design to political systems of the hemisphere. The details here merely add to the importance of Graeber’s work & due diligence in this area of study — work virtually unprecedented in his peers past or present. These details are also likely derivatives of the formulaic aspect of indigenous modes of social organization — explaining the cultural continuity in respective hemispheres. All distinct cultures of course but also self similar like the coast lines themselves, through common cosmological significations expressing beautiful social resilience in diversity. 

Graeber is also spot on in another remarkable and extremely relevant way for those of us here in this cohort together. Wage slavery is another kind of slavery we are familiar with — and this is where there is some actual real independent cultural overlap! The pre-colonial Five Nations Longhouse Confederacy was on the brink of falling into perpetual cycles of wage based slavery similar but likely also distinct from modern industrialized systems. 

This is oral documentation of nations coming out of war and into peace 2.5k yrs ago. Wampum shells for the beads on strings of sinew that was used for trade; were becoming commodified. Not from old world systems of settler colonial extraction & military market creation of course; the shells were becoming commodified by default of nations at war. War meant it simply wasn’t safe to collect these shells from the lakes. War eventually created a corrupted mind that was content to have others work for them via control of these shells. This mind was successfully transformed with matrilineal council that protected long term, against male dominant commodification of all strains of life — this lasted up until colonization. 

The League of Peace formed 2.5k yrs ago out of this empirical data matched with even older formulaic design that goes back to Sky Woman herself. This is a beautiful precedent that is desperately needed in these times. And Graeber’s words truly become prophetic in this context. @cryptowanderer @Vivek Singh @Magenta Ceiba @Sparrow Read

Here I will link the very important pieces to the cosmology --When hearing the four sacred ceremonies-- it reveals the indigenous modes that go beyond metaphor and into matrilineal law or constants. Cosmological significations protect against dogmatic tendencies--even if born into dogmatic surroundings & predominant system--by the time one has a lifetime of the numerous matrilineal ceremonies of each 13 moon cycle --the truth reveals herself in the protocols left behind via oral documentation, symbolism & cultural nuances.
The 100% consensus being included in the recitation & processes becomes all the more important in this sense as it seems to ensure this truth does not morph into self interested opinion.
The capacity for the formation of the League of Peace points to this matrilineal cosmological resilience --the matrilineal decision making process & Onakora creation being fundamental design for the Great Law of Peace & the Two Row Wampum protocols, which grew out of the matrilineal cosmology already in place.

His tone overall is a lot different, Less critical of organized religion too. He is careful not to offend what are likely a lot of his own people watching, who he knows are religious. The Great Law of Peace was even mixed with religious scriptures in the region for example. We also saw the Longhouse rewrite the only written version of the Great Law too, written by quakers. This where we learned a lot of the built in male, western perspective of native culture._
_Stuart even appeals to religious folk by making analogy of native spirituality prejudice struggles to religious prejudice struggles at one point in the video linked. Something I doubt he'd do today without critical analysis of male dominant, top down dogma.  His personal life choices & transitions from traveling iron worker -- to a dedicated father & devoted voice for his mothers song, when he refused to work on nuclear plant. The life threatening circumstances of retaining nationhood --but above all, his mother's clan mother teachings of not just matrilineal cosmology(dig the moon teachings on same channel too!) but also its protection mechanisms --The Great Law of Peace & Two Row Wampum_

Really dig this <http://revistas.ucm.es/index.php/TEKN/article/view/52267/49998|paper> that posits this:

> Recursion is a big part of recursivity but it is not the whole story. Recursion refers to a system in which  outputs  at one iteration become inputs to the   next. Feedback loops, such as a thermostat regulating temperature in an hour, would be one example. Recursion can also be visualized: self-similar repeating elements  that can be seen when holding a mirror up to another mirror, Russian nesting dolls, the chambers of a nautilus’ shell, and fractal designs like the Sierpinski triangle are all examples of recursion. Recursion is used in a more specific way in computer science, as when a function calls upon itself in order to solve a larger, more complex problem (Hofstadter 1999). 
> Recursion is a powerful concept that has a very specific definition in mathematics and computer science. I have chosen to coin the neologism “recursivity” for two reasons. First, I do not want to instigate debates about whether or not something is “truly” recursive in the mathematical   sense. 
> Recursion is a  conceptual  basis for recursivity in the same way that “equality” is a conceptual basis for democracy; one need not ask how mathematicians define equality to use it. I want to make a clear distinction between the mathematical source material I am drawing from, and the kind of social relations that recursivity promotes. Recursivity is a social condition, not the dutiful execution of a mathematical property. In the same way, a worker that has been scientifically and minutely exploited through computer-aided Taylorism embodies an idea of efficiency, but this is still a far cry from the abstraction of efficiency in physics which might require a frictionless environment, bodies with infinite hardness or other precise idealizations.

@cryptowanderer Wow mane ty kindly for this, powerful on many levels. You seem to hold a whole lot of transformative power mane. Please treat the council as we plan to treat KERNEL --and never leave haha :pray::skin-tone-5: The capacity for open ears to matrilineal indigenous words is historically easier said than done in every instance of acculturation, across geographies. Your words & temperament expressed here seem to point to more than a shift in dissonance on the individual scale, but on the collective. As we all try to work our way out of this top down fragmentation of our humanity. To embrace our respective matrilineal heritage is a great filter for recognizing what has always been, and what was most recently added or removed. This is ultimately a means for rediscovering our true place in time & space.

Here we are, gifted with pieces of know how of the stars, passed down by our mothers. The knowledge of where we are in the cycles of the stars enables us move accordingly without fear but with thankfulness, respect & ceremony for the impact of the design around us. It's this thankfulness built into cosmologies that allowed our mothers to co evolve with not just corn but with landscape scale ecosystem modification that gives us most of our food. Managed buffalo migrations even causing rising dirt to fall and fertilize soils in Europe. It's this thankfulness that allows indigenous modes of sciences to lead us to flourishing co evolution.

When hearing the gratitude you gave to the women in your life, it gives the overwhelming feeling that it's this honoring of our life givers that can get us back to designing & engineering this fecundity of co evolution :slightly_smiling_face:

Thank you so much to @Salim Virani, @Juan Diosdado, @wschwab , @Sidsel Loschenkohl, @Jason Mah and all the participants of the web3 architectures junto - an amazing conversation on the implications of decentralisation, resilience, and it's intersections with privacy.

Salim put it amazingly well: "*Political decentralisation* - creates autonomy and agency. People can act more freely and decisions get made 'closer to the source'. *Archtectural decentralisation* - creates redundancy and reliliency. *Logical decentralisation* - allows for diversity and emergence"

And thank you to Juan for pointing out that *decentralisation is the means, not the end.* The end is resilience.

After reading through @Reyna J. Perdomo’s <https://kernel-community.slack.com/archives/C022XNJ5LS3/p1645639963145069?thread_ts=1645472600.234659&cid=C022XNJ5LS3|rollercoaster of a post>, I was left with no choice but to write this message in this beautiful group that I rarely post in:

tl;dr- Thank you for the commitment all of you show, it inspires me!

tl;hr (too long, hence read)-
The commitment of everyone here is so *real* that it bamboozles me! @Kokeb Solomon, @Chaitra, @Jing Yi Teo staying up late to ask the hardest questions, @Adrian Wons preparing his pitch with a plastered hand, @Frances Han pitching his adventure from the jungle in the middle of military service, @Adam Lieber @Ali Rizvi @Salim Virani @Juan Diosdado @Pauline soaking in all that's going on and sharing it with everyone with so much care, @Hanifah Walidah refining her perfect pitch and keeping Gather alive, @Fang Chen, @Samuel He, @Daniel Ari Friedman making meaningful moves to help improve Kernel on their own, and so many more unmentioned stories with everyone whom I've had the privilege of knowing!

This scale of coordinated commitment gives me _<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%B6del,_Escher,_Bach|Eternal Golden Braid>_ vibes. Thank YOU!
Thank you @Salim Virani @Jana Cleuren @Valerie Carrillo @DAOrayaki @Anne @Andre Blas for the most inspiring moments I've had in KB5 so far :sparkles: :rainbowheart:

Thanks @sidcode. And hey @Jason Mah and @Adam Lieber. Short answer: We think it fits very well! For example, the power of AI is highly concentrated in the hands of a few. Data scientists usually don't own what they create and users of AI apps don't own their data. This means value flows to few, which will be more of an issue as AI and automation becomes a larger part of economies. We're trying to figure out what the Web3 machine learning stack looks like (e.g. storage, compute, marketplace, private AI, coordination). And also what ethics and safety looks like for decentralized AI. Would love if you were interested in getting involved!

@Adam Lieber Great to hear. Would be awesome to develop this more. When you say infrastructure, do you mean cloud? I don't think it's owned by them. I think it is owned by the tech company, who may be separate to the cloud provider. Also not sure what the T&Cs are e.g. can the cloud provider look at the data and algorithms owned by the tech company or individual?

After several months our Kernel-aided project Comic Boxels has now launched (originally YAY! Comics when in the block 3 sessions). I just wanted to say thanks to @Vivek Singh and the whole team who helped point us in the right direction throughout the program.

I wanted to say thank you to the Kernel stewards, guides & fellows for sharing their gifts of time, energy & wisdom over the last 8 weeks… At the opening session, I distinctly remember @Vivek Singh saying that “all of these opportunities already existed, Kernel is just putting them in front of you…”

Those words resonated fully with me, and I’m excited to share that during the course of Kernel, I was offered a full-time gig running community programs for Mina Foundation.

This community & ecosystem played a big part in making that possible, and I’ll be forever grateful. Thank you, thank you, thank you.

For anyone that’s going to be in Amsterdam for DevConnect - hit me up, I’d love to say hello in person!

Your conversations, and my connections with you, which have been built around the beautiful syllabus that @cryptowanderer and @Vivek Singh and the team have developed and delivered to us has impelled me to shift course. I am grateful. I wake each day with a joy and focus that springs me into the awaiting opportunities still possible. Being with you all has catalyzed me to spend the rest of my time developing gift economy communities.  The winds are. sweeping. clear the way and as Machado reminds us/me - Traveller, there is no path, you make the path by walking.  You will always walk by my side.  I am so very thankful to you all.

As we close off KB5, I would like to thank every wonderful person I meet during my adventure. Sorry being a nerd , really not good at fancy words to express my gratitude. I must say that starting Trust to Gift, every block inspired my work and encourage me to build up a better World collectively. I’m very thankful for answering my call to ‘Help’ ,it is a Gift to me. One thing I’m upset about is to not contribute grants enough, I think that every effort here should be rewarded. I wish I can help more in upcoming rounds. And lastly, Let’s keep our hearth open in the hell : <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ym4Rpd72tq8> , thanks for doing Kernel @cryptowanderer @Vivek Singh @sidcode @Aliya @Sachin Mittal  :sunflower:

To @Vivek Singh’s point on Dostoyevsky on the call just now, a fascinating and pertinent reflection as we come to the end of KB5.

At 27 Fyodor Dostoyevsky was arrested and sentenced to death for his association with a literary society deemed a threat by the Tsarist regime in December 1849. Costumed in a white shirt, Dostoyevsky kneeled in a public square in Saint Petersburg awaiting execution. Having pressed his lips to a cross and read his death sentence a ceremonial sabre was lifted high above his neck. In that moment, Dostoyevsky was inescapably aware that these were his final breaths.

Suddenly the spectacle was abandoned as the Tsar announced Dostoyevsky’s life would be pardoned. Dostoyevsky was instead to be sent to a labour camp in Siberia which would be followed by several years of military services, in exile. The whole spectacle in the square had been a publicity stunt; an attempt to depict the despot as a benevolent ruler.

Having been spared his life, Dostoyevsky immediately penned his new-found appreciation for life in an immortal letter to his Brother, within which featured the following words:

_“I’m not despondent and I haven’t lost heart. Life is everywhere, life is in us ourselves, not outside. There will be people by my side, and to be a human being among people and to remain one forever, no matter in what circumstances, not to grow despondent and not to lose heart — that’s what life is all about, that’s its task. I have come to recognise that.”_

Thank you, KB5.

P.s. there are no links between @Vivek Singh and any Tsarist regime (as far as I’m aware…)

Vivek has fostered a global community through mindful conversations. I met Vivek at a <https://youtu.be/5PEfGmujb3Y|Gitcoin event> in the Spring of 2021. Through our conversation, I was inspired to apply for Kernel. Being a Kernel Fellow gave me access to the most dynamic conversations I have experienced in Web3 through weekly Firesides and community organized juntos. 

In August, Vivek attended my virtual <https://youtu.be/yV6yL3joF0Q|NFT Birthday party>. He had on a really cool hat and got to meet some people that have known me my whole life. He also picked a <https://opensea.io/assets/matic/0x2953399124f0cbb46d2cbacd8a89cf0599974963/52084976433308082057548704829773600857536488711956120813222680999376845799427/|dopalicious NFT> that has continued to inspire my art. I appreciate you for taking time to celebrate and enjoy that <https://opensea.io/assets/matic/0x2953399124f0cbb46d2cbacd8a89cf0599974963/52084976433308082057548704829773600857536488711956120813222681009272450449411/|special day> with us.  

A few months after Kernel Block III, we met in person. We went to one of my favorite restaurants in ATL with our families. The night was so inspiring that I sealed it with an original poem and homemade vegan desserts. 

Later that year, I reached out to Vivek to sponsor a <https://operasneaker.notion.site/NFT-NYC-Kernel-Art-Dinner-727eca0c044e4386a2457066f6817a16|Kernel Dinner during NFT.NYC>. He provided the <https://operasneaker.notion.site/operasneaker/Opera-Sneaker-e912ec5b2f19476bbd24cafaf48baf53|Opera Sneaker> artist collective with a beautiful venue and deliciously catered food. We hosted Kernel fellows and local artists for a night full of art, conversation and love. 

Today, Vivek has led the Kernel community to over 1,000 Fellows as we enter Kernel Block V. The Kernel community has given me a space to develop my skills as a technologist, artist and entrepreneur. I am grateful for my experiences in Kernel that have inspired my art and pushed my creativity. 

Through this community, I have met people from all over the world drawn into the wonder of Kernel for different reasons— all connected by the spark to innovate. Through people like @Vivek Singh, I have listened and learned how to be a better friend to myself and others. 

Peace and love,

Tagan

I am so thankful!

There are far too many people to thank but here goes. Thanks for letting me cry in Twitter Spaces today @Vivek Singh @alisha @Angela Gilhotra @cryptowanderer @Sachin Mittal. In KB4, I've bonded, spent time with or been in the presence with these amazingly inspirational womxn of color @Vienna Looi @Songyi Lee @Holly Grimm @Jasmine Wang @Michelle Ma @Denise Schaefer @Rebecca Mqamelo @Juanna Zhai. I've been so moved by the work of @Richard Blythman @Matthew Scott Jones that I hope for the future of the “metaverse” and AI, places where I have felt trapped in centralized recreating inequalities for so long, that it's such a fresh breathe of air to see these amazing founders for their work and I can't wait to see more from them and work with them somehow in some fashion at the intersection as its relevant with my work in the future. I have an extremely long list of all the folks who demo’ed today at Showcase and Expo that I either plan on somehow integrating into in my future work (be a user, beta tester, adviser on their platform). Thank you (Salamat) again to @Alex Yao Lisa Lee Lucas (co-founder of NOVA with @Nicolas Nicolas Ponette) and Michelle Tsing (laptopradio and blockchain adviser to some companies out of Kernel and Blockchain at Berkeley accelerator) for pushing me to apply. I almost didn't and I am so glad I did. It is really encouraging me to do all the things I want to with DAOs, to not compromise my values, and stay true to myself, in a world obsessed with performative isms that is the Hollywood/Silicon Valley/DC/NY power and wealth hungry addicted and controlling egos that I try so hard to resist. Today I quit 3 social media networks, dropped 3 projects that no longer made sense, and am deciding to double down on what I believe is authentic to my nature and being, that will continue to serve me well personally and professionally in my work. Thank you so much for helping me verbally process, grow, raise hard and contentious questions and receive so many more resources and feedback I am still processing I feel like I did 5 MOOCs and a degrrr in Kernel it was far more than I expected than a YC, graduate degree, or self-help coaching session. This has been powerful for me as a community organizer, entrepreneur, software engineer, computational designer, as a woman of color, colonized person, and avid reader. I so appreciate all the hard work it takes to create content, organize logistics, moderate, facilitate, and maintain as a steward and also much love to every single person in the Kernel community who has been responsive with every chat, every request, and every ask I have made whether verbal, written or otherwise. I am constantly amazed by this community and am so privileged to be a part of it. It's been an honor to be selected as a fellow and I can only hope I live up to what I set out to do next now with a framework that helps heal me and keep me grounded away from a hamster wheel that is life. I am taking a major cooling period after December and hope to share more work come 2022 with Kernel (maybe a future showcase), of all that's been incubating and cooking up in my head, behind Code editors and things I haven't pushed to GitHub, announced or made live yet. Lastly, thank you @Kevin Owocki for founding GitCoin, seeing you speak at Dystopia Labs and other conferences over the years always impressed me and I'm floored to have participated somehow in some small way related remotely to the work that you do, it is so important for the liberation of all people in the world and I hope that it continues to evolve with each Kernel block in the future.

I thought I'd drop a line here as I'm just jumping back into Kernel after quite a time away.  My web3 journey didn't start with Kernel but it did start with Gitcoin back in early 2019 after I heard a podcast with @Kevin Owocki that was my first step down the rabbit hole.  After hacking away on bounties for more than year (quite a few for Gitcoin Core), I saw the first mentions of the Kernel program and applied.  After a fruitful interview with @Vivek Singh and @Sachin Mittal, I waited a few weeks and wondered if I'd ever hear back.  I feel like the poster child for imposter syndrome in the web3 world and I was more than surprised when I got the email inviting me to join the Kernel Genesis Block.  The rest, as they say, is history.  I'm thankful for having been included in this community of builders and thinkers and also for the whole Gitcoin community of growing open source .  I'm definitely not the deepest thinker here or the best coder (not by a country mile), but it was this community that really helped me find my footing to go from where I was (someone who felt purposeless and unfruitful in my then vocation) to where I am now (an active, engaged dev working on Ethereum infrastructure who wakes up every day excited to do what I've been called to do and to see the world get turned upside down by what we're building).  So thank you @Kevin Owocki for building Gitcoin, @Vivek Singh, @Sachin Mittal,  and@cryptowanderer for Kernel, and to others along the way who have given me opportunities to build cool stuff and to be a part of web3 like @Rob Secord and @Ben Lakoff from Charged Particles, @Mike Elias from Idea Market, various folks from the Status/Nimbus team, @Shresth Agrawal, @Jose Aguinaga...etc.

My web3 journey didn't start with Kernel but it did start with Gitcoin back in early 2019 after I heard a podcast with @Kevin Owocki that was my first step down the rabbit hole.  After hacking away on bounties for more than year (quite a few for Gitcoin Core), I saw the first mentions of the Kernel program and applied.  After a fruitful interview with @Vivek Singh and @Sachin Mittal, I waited a few weeks and wondered if I'd ever hear back.  I feel like the poster child for imposter syndrome in the web3 world and I was more than surprised when I got the email inviting me to join the Kernel Genesis Block.  The rest, as they say, is history.  I'm thankful for having been included in this community of builders and thinkers and also for the whole Gitcoin community of growing open source .  I'm definitely not the deepest thinker here or the best coder (not by a country mile), but it was this community that really helped me find my footing to go from where I was (someone who felt purposeless and unfruitful in my then vocation) to where I am now (an active, engaged dev working on Ethereum infrastructure who wakes up every day excited to do what I've been called to do and to see the world get turned upside down by what we're building).  So thank you @Kevin Owocki for building Gitcoin, @Vivek Singh, @Sachin Mittal,  and@cryptowanderer for Kernel, and to others along the way who have given me opportunities to build cool stuff and to be a part of web3 like @Rob Secord and @Ben Lakoff from Charged Particles, @Mike Elias from Idea Market, various folks from the Status/Nimbus team, @Shresth Agrawal, @Jose Aguinaga...etc.

I applied to KERNEL on Nov 11th, 2020.

I had very little crypto experience to speak of, no idea what I wanted to work on, and frankly hadn’t done anything too impressive in the startup space before that either. I’m not sure why @Vivek Singh and @Sachin Mittal took a chance on me and invited me to Block 2, but I am very grateful that they did so.

On Friday, the <https://sherlock.xyz/|protocol> I co-founded during Block 2 <https://twitter.com/Sherlock_DeFi/status/1441435528319098885|launched> on mainnet with <https://app.sherlock.xyz/|$30M in TVL> and our first customer. It was a huge milestone and the culmination of a lot work. It’s still only the beginning of the journey, but I wanted to take a second and express my thanks to KERNEL for helping us get this far.

I am especially grateful to Vivek, Sachin and all the stewards and mentors of KERNEL. Sherlock would not be in this position without all of their help and guidance. Our first advisor was a KERNEL mentor, our lead investor came from KERNEL, and dozens of crucial early intros came through KERNEL.

I feel extremely lucky to be a part of this community and I hope the progress we’ve made since Block 2 can embolden those in Block 4 to seize the most of their experience and personalize it for their unique journeys. And of course, feel free to reach out if you think I can help along the way.

Hey all, time flew, and now with things calming down a bit, I want to express my gratitude towards those that made the past few months so special, It was a big wave for me and ethblockart, and without the help of mentors, fellows, and the kernel team, I wouldn't have been able to stay atop the surfboard!

For starters, I wanna express my gratitude towards many of the mentors, present and supportive in genuinely important ways throughout this adventure: Defi_Dad, @Thomas Klocanas, @Linda Xie, @Shawn Cheng @Ben Lakoff, @Dave Rodman, @Harsh Rajat and @Scott Moore. You folks are amazing and your help instrumental.

Other fellows, always positive, helpful and inspiring in the best way possible even while busy with their own adventures, like @Simon Fremaux, @Carter Carlson and the best-practices gang, @Holly Grimm, and the DADA team, even if we didn't interact much directly, know you've been an inspiration for many years!

And how can we not be grateful for the Kernel team, receiving us all with open arms and unparalleled patience and kindness, @Sachin Mittal, @Vivek Singh and others, one-of-a-kind human beings which I'm honoured to have met and spend time with. :pray:

Lastly, I can't write this without a special note to @cryptowanderer, embracing the project mission from the start, contributing in ways I couldn't have expected, making what the project is today a reality, you're amazing, thank you again.

One can say riding a market like we're experiencing today as a solo builder with a somewhat market-fit product can feel like choosing Jaws, Maui as a go-to surf spot while still learning to surf, sure some can pull off the once-in-a-lifetime herculean task of achieving so alone...But what enables surfers to, time and time again, execute this impressive feat, a humbling celebration of our ability to face head-first the scariest challenges posed by nature, are exactly other humans, community, supporters often not celebrated, from the tow-in jet sky riders, the lifeguards bringing you oxygen, to the chanting crowd by the coast and even the sharks keeping you alert.

Back to the point, what is being done here at Kernel is unique, every step planned with a level of care hard to find elsewhere, and it is also upon us all to keep this flame awake and the kernel culture principled, I hope to in the future be able to help others the same way I was helped here, for that is what makes the world go round.

For now, thank you Kernel, for all, and happy spring! :seedling:

Here are left over thoughts & some notes from our last Junto that may lend to David’s thoughts on indigenous influence in our urgent times. His great articulation of the benefits of consensus & the creation of new bottom up structures-- seems to speak to where the weight of transformative power of indigenous dialogue resides. Not having to start from scratch in autonomous creation of new sustainable structures is a huge advantage we shouldn’t take for granted on any front.

Insights to western misnomers of indigenous social structures through a matrilineal indigenous & _Kanienke'ha'ka perspective (misnomer - Mohawk)_: 

Female/Male Chief = “The Best of us”-- chosen by women title-holders with 100% consensus decision making. “(De)horned” by women when deemed ineligible for title. No campaigns or elections, to avoid any “perception of corruption.” Perceptions of possible pillow talk amongst representatives means title-holders can not be married to each other for example.

Hereditary - Is reference to clan —not blood, or immediate family. Used as mechanism to protect against nepotism or any “perceptions of corruption,” not to ensure nepotism as in the western context. Even if not blood & across the territory for example— inter clan marriage is illegal. Representatives can not hand down title to their children-- as in the western meaning of hereditary monarchies. Clan is blood only in the case that legally clan can only be given by mother to children. If your mother is does not have a clan but your father does you are his  “__” clan “hung about the neck.” This becomes relevant in case of legal title eligibility. 

Elected Tribal or Band councils across the hemisphere today do not abide by any of these native constitution laws —their chief title only being legal in context of municipalities of respective colonial nations — which means they have signed away their rightful nation to nation status of the Two Row Wampum Peace Treaty. We can never express our gratitude to the women of the Longhouse in Kahnawake, who have kept this Peace Treaty alive for us to leverage today. 

Slavery - The Longhouse is adamant about the absence of slavery in the hemisphere. The Longhouse is also always careful not to speak on the protocols of other native nations. So this strong stance on slavery is likely a reference to the continuity that also exist amongst those distinctions—from a common history & cosmology “the journey of the corn.”

This is consistent with the Longhouse’s oral documentation of “the bringing into the heart fire” concept of indigenous ”justice systems.” Hereditary in the indigenous context becomes important in Wengrow’s mention of “hereditary slavery”--because it likely points to an adoption into clan mechanism, merely getting lost in an ethnographic translation. To jail or imprison a human being in Longhouse oral documentation has always been illegal. So it follows that anything even closely resembling the chattel style slavery we attach to the word would inherently be deemed illegal as well. The worst of crimes meant being marked on the face as the worst of offenders, to be easily identified by surrounding nations -- then let free in to the wilderness. Or killed immediately for the heinous offense. 

Hinting at possible matrilineal continuity across oceans — this is also consistent with other matrilineal justice mechanisms of Africa. Mentioned by polymath, physicist, anthropologist, archaeologist, linguist, historian —Cheikh Anta Diop. Diop describes precolonial west African nations having intricate protocols for bringing local/regional rule benders into the family for a determined period of time —after which it was then illegal to ever disparage the person by even mentioning the crime or this time of the person’s life. 

This last nuance actually points to elaborate cultural protections against free labor —as does clan adoption via “bringing into the heart fire” in the native context. 

Chattel slavery is largely dependent on quite the contrary elaborate cultural mechanisms of dehumanization — rhetoric of infidels was just as pop culture as minstrel shows, toys, cartoons food labels & children restaurants called “Little Black Sambo” as recent as the 80s here in the states for example. These indigenous systems seem to be humanizing as much as possible with protections against dehumanization.

This makes lot more sense than this “heart fire” phrasing being a sick euphemism for what is the Islamic origin of chattel slavery ,in which we are the most familiar in the west. As Graeber mentions the folks in the 1500s having a hard time believing natives had even heard of Jesus let alone (or practice human sacrifice to demons) denounce him. This may be a continuation of this same phenomenon via the slavery misnomer that is rooted in old world religious, political & economic systems. Far removed from a precolonial native world. 

“The forgotten slave trade” of east Africa & what was then — extensions of these east African nations into the Middle East. Resulted in an ethnic cleansing not unlike what has happened in modern Palestine in our lifetime. It also lasted long enough to overlap with the west African slave trade. 
Not unlike our real time awareness of geopolitics today, important history of both eras of African slavery are largely lost to highly politicized & or religious narratives, somehow skipping over indigenous spiritual/cultural influence in the regions for millenia. Diop mentions interesting west African context often left out — the “bringing into the heart fire” style justice systems were still intact in these still precolonial black African nations — this was exploited by slave traders before raids became necessary because these nations rose to the defense of their people after discovering the crime. 

None of this takes away from Graeber’s overall point of empirical political data over millenia giving robust design to political systems of the hemisphere. The details here merely add to the importance of Graeber’s work & due diligence in this area of study — work virtually unprecedented in his peers past or present. These details are also likely derivatives of the formulaic aspect of indigenous modes of social organization — explaining the cultural continuity in respective hemispheres. All distinct cultures of course but also self similar like the coast lines themselves, through common cosmological significations expressing beautiful social resilience in diversity. 

Graeber is also spot on in another remarkable and extremely relevant way for those of us here in this cohort together. Wage slavery is another kind of slavery we are familiar with — and this is where there is some actual real independent cultural overlap! The pre-colonial Five Nations Longhouse Confederacy was on the brink of falling into perpetual cycles of wage based slavery similar but likely also distinct from modern industrialized systems. 

This is oral documentation of nations coming out of war and into peace 2.5k yrs ago. Wampum shells for the beads on strings of sinew that was used for trade; were becoming commodified. Not from old world systems of settler colonial extraction & military market creation of course; the shells were becoming commodified by default of nations at war. War meant it simply wasn’t safe to collect these shells from the lakes. War eventually created a corrupted mind that was content to have others work for them via control of these shells. This mind was successfully transformed with matrilineal council that protected long term, against male dominant commodification of all strains of life — this lasted up until colonization. 

The League of Peace formed 2.5k yrs ago out of this empirical data matched with even older formulaic design that goes back to Sky Woman herself. This is a beautiful precedent that is desperately needed in these times. And Graeber’s words truly become prophetic in this context. @cryptowanderer @Vivek Singh @Magenta Ceiba @Sparrow Read

This is a message of gratitude to @Kris Is, who showed up at CICOLAB yesterday and gave us some great advice to check out Dandelion Mané and Source Cred. This actually was not necessarily an obvious link, because Source Cred has been coming at their solution from "reputation," and we have been talking about "matching." (See here for a history of this idea: <https://miro.com/app/board/o9J_lYxOK30=/>). If you watch this <https://youtu.be/Ee99RK5_Jtg|condensed video (6 min)> of last night's discussion, you can see an example of what we call "discoverability," which is huge problem within Kernel. This is because it is a highly innovative space, with high diversity of people from different backgrounds. That means that people might be working on different projects which might actually align in some way, but that is difficult to see on the surface (in other words, they would not be able to find each other using Google because of non-obvious search terms and lack of common language between different fields, or by simply listing what their project is about).  It takes a deeper dive into figuring out the "why" of what people are trying to do with their projects. So, thanks, Kris, for taking that time and making a really great connection which saved me so much work. You are a lifesaver.

In last night's session, we talked about Appreciation Bytes, our super-simple tool for noticing the often-invisible contributions of others which add to group intelligence. Our hypothesis is that we could use this to facilitate matching between a mess of groups, people, and projects, especially in a community-wide funding effort. It turns out that we have been working on the front end to what Source Cred has been developing the back end, and there is probably a high incidence of that in Kernel. Developing the machine and human technology to be able to put the memetic puzzles pieces together is a fascinating mission and one we look forward to helping to solve during our time at Kernel. @Sachin Mittal @Vivek Singh @Charles Blass

Hello, excuse me for being so late to the party. I was out in the boonies (no internet) and then moving across town... I cannot believe Kernel is already over. It was sometimes tough for me to participate due to time zones but I tried to make it work the best it could. Like others, it meant that I missed some pretty interesting discussions but I was happy to listen to recordings later. It was 'tough' to work through Kernel with a hardware project, especially seeing the heavy ETH focus (in a good way)! It was fun nonetheless and got some feedback I still have to work through. As an upside, we recently applied for a grant to take the first steps into taking int into production. We aim to incorporate in Singapore due to logistic and strategic reasons, as our researched showed that Asia is the fastest growing hardware market. I talked and received feedback from many people, and for that you have my thanks! To all the others I did not get a chance to talk, perhaps we see each other in a next round. I will stick around in these Slack channels for as long as they continue to exist. I debated joining APOLLO but with some of the stuff coming up, it is too much to manage. I'd love to keep in touch or if anyone wants to reach out and join the fun. Interested in talking to people from all backgrounds. Also, we are open to investment opportunities. Cheers all! Finally, a special thanks to @Vivek Singh and @Sachin Mittal for creating the programme.

I'm extremely grateful for having the opportunity to have interacted with the most passionate, talented, generous and philanthropic community I've ever had the fortune of coming into contact with. The range of concepts, fierce intellect and enormous compassion that I've been exposed to will be unforgettable.

When I started, I was deeply apathetic about the future of the human experience. But I leave KERNEL with a deep sense of optimism, tremendous excitement, and hope for humanity. You are all inspiring people, and I'm indebted to everyone who held my hand into the Web3 rabbit hole.

The world now appears as beautiful to me as it once had when I was a little kid. And I really mean that. Maybe that's Beginner's Mind.

U031DBK4459.message: Thanks for everything, Kernel. I'm filled with joy at all the connections I've made and the great conversations I've had. More than that, I'm looking forward to the conversations I'm going TO have! In no particular order @cryptowanderer's fantastic and challenging syllabus, @Ali Rizvi's great chats, @Greg Bateman's good suggestions, @Danny Gattas's invitations to be a part of the DeFi Guild and @horsefacts's great intro to MEV. @Salim Virani big thanks for making the sessions more interactive! All of you who attended our chats, esp @Adam Lieber (your enthusiasm to learn is inspiring) and @Juan Diosdado / @Cedric Tiu /@Jason Mah /@Yajie Wang thanks again! Thanks to @Vivek Singh for being the glue that holds this all together. It was also great to connect with @Kokeb Solomon and @Jonathan Brun in real life. Super excited to see where this all goes in the future!

After reading through @Reyna J. Perdomo’s <https://kernel-community.slack.com/archives/C022XNJ5LS3/p1645639963145069?thread_ts=1645472600.234659&cid=C022XNJ5LS3|rollercoaster of a post>, I was left with no choice but to write this message in this beautiful group that I rarely post in:

tl;dr- Thank you for the commitment all of you show, it inspires me!

tl;hr (too long, hence read)-
The commitment of everyone here is so *real* that it bamboozles me! @Kokeb Solomon, @Chaitra, @Jing Yi Teo staying up late to ask the hardest questions, @Adrian Wons preparing his pitch with a plastered hand, @Frances Han pitching his adventure from the jungle in the middle of military service, @Adam Lieber @Ali Rizvi @Salim Virani @Juan Diosdado @Pauline soaking in all that's going on and sharing it with everyone with so much care, @Hanifah Walidah refining her perfect pitch and keeping Gather alive, @Fang Chen, @Samuel He, @Daniel Ari Friedman making meaningful moves to help improve Kernel on their own, and so many more unmentioned stories with everyone whom I've had the privilege of knowing!

This scale of coordinated commitment gives me _<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%B6del,_Escher,_Bach|Eternal Golden Braid>_ vibes. Thank YOU!

@cryptowanderer @Sylvia R @Will Cove @Dashiell Bark-Huss @Derya Karli @Paulo Almeida @Juan Diosdado @Kundan @Kokeb Solomon @Ahmed Yusuf Thank you guys for your kind words! Really made our day :heart: :blush:

Thanks to all of you. And last night's breakout with @Shilo @Jason Mah @Sertac Guven @Hana Azab and @Kokeb Solomon was grounding  :ok_hand::skin-tone-3::pray: lots more gratitude to give.

U031FL4Q4AY.message: I begin this post-Kernel weeks with overwhelming gratitude for the profound support I have received as I embark on helping people build Gift Economy communities. I am drawing heavily on Module 7. Thank you @Christina Trout and @cryptowanderer and my unseen wisdom guides who know it is possible to build a new world, starting now with simplicity and love.

Thank-you for the people that joined the ancenstal futures conversations @Renata Morais for convening this space @Rachel Chak for your amazing resources @Christina Trout  for regenerative stewardship @Andre Blas  for remembering connection @Salim Virani for asking better questions @Anika Qureshi for sharing your insight from the longhouse conversation @Renya for embodied intelligence. @Bacely YoroBi for the simple methods to preserve and remember > narrative routine ritual. @Sparrow Read for offering a piece in this puzzle. Here's to the ancestral futures that we each embody as designers of here and now and ancestors of the future. To have these conversation and hear your stories is (for me)to live and honor our (tangatawhenua) ancestral oral heritage which has always been shared through narrative, Thank you :kernel-love:

@Christina Trout I’m so curious about your step father as well! What an amazing thing it would be—to be a fly on the wall. I just went to your notion page and jumping out at me is, “The All is in the small”.  How true that is. Love the work you are doing and excited for the hope it brings. Overall I am very appreciative of this space ‘Ancestral Futures’. You all are inspiring. Ancient Future as a concept that grounds life has been stuck with me for a number of years and this idea of shared wisdom across all ages and generations. Spaces that acknowledge, listen, and share wisdom. Appreciation of the individual within the whole. Cultivating and hoping to share something soon.
